Award.AwardTitle: Theory of thermoelastic properties of iron bearing minerals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Thermoelastic properties of minerals and melts are the crucial link that permit seismic tomography images of the Earth's interior to be translated into information of geophysical significance: mineralogy, composition, and temperature. Over the last decade, enormous advances have been made in our ability to compute elastic properties of materials under the extreme conditions of Earth's interior using only the fundamental constants of nature as input. Nevertheless, great challenges remain, especially regarding iron bearing minerals. In oxides and silicates, iron has magnetic moment and its electrons are strongly correlated. Materials with strongly correlated electrons have challenged theorists for more than half century and mantle minerals are among the most complex of them. Besides, their behavior must be understood at extreme conditions of pressures and temperatures, which change their magnetic state, a phenomenon known as spin transition. Under this grant novel methods based on the DFT+U approach will be applied to investigate spin transitions and its consequences for the thermoelastic properties of the most important phases of Earth's lower mantle: ferropericlase, ferromagnesium silicate perovskite and postperovskite. Fe2O3 is a possible stable phase at the core-mantle boundary and an ideal material for testing the new methods. Atomic vibrations, atomic diffusion, and collective magnetic excitations will be studied to shed light on the thermal, elastic, rheological, and transport properties of these phases and of the mantle.

The outcome of this research will be essential input for researchers investigating the state and evolution of the mantle. The novel methods, whose development is being stimulated especially by mineral physics, have been implemented in the open source at initio materials simulation package Quantum ESPRESSO. They will be available in subsequent releases of the package to the mineral physics and materials communities. The PIs are deeply involved with education and outreach programs that include a) training of graduate students and post-docs, b) training of undergraduates through summer internships offered through the Minnesota Supercomputing Institute, and c) giving tutorials to the materials and mineral physics community.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seismic data offers direct information about Earth’s interior and can be combined to provide tomographic images of seismic velocity structures. The latter contains detailed evidence of the state and processes occurring on the planet. The goal of this project is to provide the data needed and make possible the interpretation of these tomographic images. To do so, we perform quantum mechanical calculations based on density functional theory (DFT) of acoustic velocities in minerals at high pressures and temperatures. These predictive results in a large number of phases allow us to address the origin of these structures as a function of mineralogy, composition, and temperature providing insights on geophysical processes operating deep inside the Earth.

In this project, we have tackled a novel phenomenon in materials and mineral physics, the pressure and temperature induced a spin state change in iron in deep Earth’s forming phases. High pressure and temperature experiments have revealed previously unknown phenomena about these spin “transitions”. Similar to structural phase transitions they produce changes in density and acoustic velocities in these minerals. However, in contrast to structural transitions, these changes are strongly temperature dependent – the pressure range of the spin “transition” broadens with increasing temperature. For this reason, they are referred to as “spin crossovers”. These crossovers cause strange and unusual effects such as a decrease in compressibility with increasing temperature.

 

In the last funding period, we have unraveled important novel effects spin crossovers have on seismic velocities. First, their signatures on longitudinal (P) and shear (S) seismic wave velocities are very different. Second, they make P-wave velocities more insensitive to lateral temperature variations at ~ 1500-2000 km depth. Third, they increase the sensitivity of P and S waves to compositional variations, such as changes in Mg/Si ratio or iron content in lower mantle phases. Finally, the depth range of these effects depends on the local temperature. All these effects disrupt the usual correlation between P and S wave velocity changes making the interpretation of seismic tomography maps more elaborate. These novel effects caused by spin crossovers are indispensable for future interpretations of tomographic images.
